NEWS.TITLE: KCTV [War Veterans]
NEWS.TEXT:
[Ŀ] The provincial government began ten years ago to affix special signboards to the houses of locally-residing war veterans. As Mike Balfour now reports, over 5,000 of the signs have been put up to honor the national heroes.
[Ʈ] The 2nd Vietnamese war lasted from 1960 to 1975.
Great numbers of Korean troops were dispatched to the conflict.
68-year-old (â) Moon Chang-hyu served in the army as medic for two years and was in the center of the Vietnamese battle.
Attesting that fact, in front of Moon's house there is a signboard saying 'Vietnamese War Veteran's House'.
< Interview : Moon Chang-hyu >
To honor of persons of national merit, Jeju started the signboard-making project in 2003. It was the first such project in the nation.
At first, the signboards were plastic, but their color faded with time. The plaques are now made of brass.
The new brass castings were attached to the houses of more than 3000 Korean War veterans in 2011.
Last year, the project was expanded to more than 2800 men of national merit including war veterans who fought in Vietnam.
The Jeju Regional Office of Patriot and Veterans Affairs said some more veterans will be added to the project.
In the future they plan to attach the signboard to homes of military personnel who are designated as persons of national merit.
< Interview : Kang Dong-hwa >
Attaching plaques to homes is a small gesture that reminds us of the huge sacrifice of war veterans who fought for their country.
Mike Balfour KCTV.

NEWS.TITLE: Arirang [Film Industry ]
NEWS.TEXT:
[Ŀ] Turning back to Arirang now, the domestic film industry has been undergoing what many critics say is a renaissance, with a string of critical and commercial successes at home and abroad. However, the onslaught of Hollywood blockbusters this summer has sharply cut into box-office sales, as homegrown movies struggle to attract local audiences. Arirang's Paul Yi has more.
[Ʈ] The Hollywood action movie "Iron Man 3" has been attracting audiences
[Nearly nine million Iron Man 3 tickets sold in SK] nationwide, capturing record-breaking ticket sales of nearly 9 million in Korea since its premiere just over a month ago.
The special effects extravaganza was screened at over 1,300 theaters in its first week, accounting for more than half of all movie screenings in the country.
But for a growing number of moviegoers, the way the film and other blockbusters like it have limited the selection at local theaters has become frustrating.
[Interview] Yoo Ye-eun / Seoul resident "There are really a lot of show times for 'Iron Man,' so it seems like this theater and other ones are only screening this movie. There don't seem to be many screening times or options for seeing other films."
[Interview] Gong Yeong-hoon / Seoul resident "It seems like there's nothing but 'Iron Man 3,' whether it's upcoming screenings or films playing now. Because of that, there aren't any other movies to choose from. It's like you're just returning to the same thing."
The local movie industry has also been feeling the pressure.
Last month, homegrown films including "Born to Sing" and "Boomerang Family" all fell short of their box-office expectations.
[Korean films' market share dropped to 30.5% in May ] According to the Korean Film Council, Korean films' share of the local movie market hit its lowest level in more than three years last month.
That's been due in part to heavy competition from Hollywood blockbusters, with "World War Z" featuring Brad Pitt set to dominate ticket sales later this month.
['Secretly & Greatly' breaks opening day box-office record] However, the new Korean film "Secretly and Greatly" managed to surpass half a million in ticket sales on its opening day this past week.
The film's surging success has given renewed hope to local filmmakers who still face tough times ahead.
[Interview] Shim Young-seob / Movie critic "The amount of planning that goes into a blockbuster has decreased a lot. On the other hand, creative directors who undertake original thrillers, noir or experimental pieces take a lot of time, but lack successful box-office hits."
[Arirang News] Paul Yi Experts say the Korean film industry has matured considerably in recent years, however it's going to take greater cooperation between local independent filmmakers and theater owners to ensure interest remains high.
Paul Yi, Arirang News.

NEWS.TITLE: Kim Han-wook appointed chief director of JDC
NEWS.TEXT:
Administration
Kim Han-wook appointed chief director of JDC
Sixth to hold position at Jeju Free International City Development Center
Former lieutenant governor (ѿ) Kim Han-wook has become the sixth chief director of the Jeju Free International City Development Center.
The Ministry of Land, Infrastructure and Transport appointed Kim to the position June 7th.
The 65-year-old hails from (ȴ) Andeok-myeon, Seogwipo. He graduated from () Ohyun High School and the Graduate School of Policy Studies at Korea University. In addition to a stint as lieutenant governor, Kim also served as the director of both the Provincial Planning and Management Department and the National Archives.
He was inaugurated Monday at the Jeju Science Park.
JDC ̻忡 ѿ Ӹ
ֱð߼ 6 ̻忡 ѿ 簡 Ӹƽϴ.
䱳δ (7)ڷ ѿ 縦 ֱð߼ ̻ Ӹ߽ϴ.
65 ̻ ȴ åп , ֵ ȹ ġ Ͽ, ֵ ߽ϴ.
̻ ӽ 10 ÷ܰб ϴ.

NEWS.TITLE: Fire at airport military warehouse
NEWS.TEXT:
Society
Fire at airport military warehouse
No casualties or flight disruptions
A fire broke out around 11:10 Monday morning in the food supply warehouse for Navy Squadron 615 at Jeju International Airport in (㵿) Yongdam-dong, Jeju City.
Luckily, there were no casualties, but the blaze did burn food and other warehouse contents. It was extinguished within just 15 minutes.
All flights landed and took off normally throughout the day.
Military and fire department authorities descended on the scene to investigate and question witnesses.
ְ δ â ȭ װ ''
11 10 ֽ 㵿 ֱ ر 615 â ϴ.
ȭ θش ϰ ִ ¿ 15 ü ȭƽϴ.
װ ׵ǰ , 籹 ҹ İ
Ȯ ϰ ֽϴ.

NEWS.TITLE: Headlines (June 10)
NEWS.TEXT:
1. <Fire Monday at airport military warehouse> A fire broke out Monday morning at a military warehouse at Jeju International Airport.
2. <Kim Han-wook appointed chief director of JDC> The land ministry has appointed a former lieutenant governor as the new chief director of the JDC.
3. <Seoul announces roadmap to 70% employment rate> The current employment rate in the country stands at around 64%, but President Park has vowed to push it up to 70%.
4. <Plaques honor local war veterans> The provincial government has affixed thousands of memorial plaques to the houses of local war veterans.

NEWS.TITLE: Province plans 'cruise zone' in Gangjeong
NEWS.TEXT:
Administration
Province plans 'cruise zone' in Gangjeong
Officials to select main contractor for \12.8b project this month
The province is planning on developing a 'cruise zone' in the village of () Gangjeong, Seogwipo, where a port for both military vessels and cruise ships is under construction.
The provincial government is planning to spend 12.8 billion won through the year 2015 on the development, and it will select a main contractor for the project this month.
The zone will cover 21,500 square meters of land between the Gangjeong village center and the harbor.
Once complete, it will include stores selling island specialties, restaurants, and night markets.
, ũ׸ Ÿ

NEWS.TITLE: Info & Events (June 10)
NEWS.TEXT:
Members of the art class at Seolmundae Women's Cultural Center are displaying their creations.
Title - 'Drawing with Passion'
Date - Through June 15
Venue - Seolmundae Women's Cultural Center
Info - swcenter.jeju.go.kr
Details - Landscapes and flowers
Twenty-six Buddhist statues are on display at Jeju National Museum.
Title - Buddhist Statues of Korea
Date - Through June 16
Venue - Jeju National Museum
Info - jeju.museum.go.kr
Details - 26 important statues
Jeju Museum of Art is displaying the creations of Jang Li-seok.
Title - 'Chadori's Haenyeo Mom'
Date - Through June 16
Venue - Jeju Museum of Art
Info - jmoa.jeju.go.kr

NEWS.TITLE: Jeju City beaches to officially open in late June
NEWS.TEXT:
Tourism
Jeju City beaches to officially open in late June
Iho to open June 22, five others on the 28th
Authorities will officially open Jeju City's six beaches near the end of the month.
Iho Taewu Beach will be the first to open June 22, while the others, including those in () Samyang and () Gwakji will open June 28.
Those in (Դ) Hamdeok, () Samyang, (ȣ) Iho, and () Hyupjae will stay open into the night from July 13 through August 20.
In order to keep everyone safe, Jeju City will be stationing more lifeguards and jellyfish monitors at the beaches than in previous years. It has also spent 500 million won on renovations to shower booths, changing rooms, and other facilities.

NEWS.TITLE: Shilla Duty Free Shop to get two additional floors
NEWS.TEXT:
Economy
Shilla Duty Free Shop to get two additional floors
Yeon-dong location to have six stories by August 2014
Two floors will be added to the (Ŷ) Shilla Duty Free Shop in () Yeon-dong, Jeju City.
Municipal officials say they gave permission for the business to expand from a four-floor to a six-floor structure as long as it expands the parking lot, as well.
Construction will begin as early as this month, and it is scheduled for completion in August 2014.
The board of directors for Hotel Shilla decided in April to expand the Jeju City shop.

NEWS.TITLE: Jeju City apartment fire: residents evacuated
NEWS.TEXT:
Society
Jeju City apartment fire: residents evacuated
Two sent to hospital for smoke inhalation after Friday morning blaze
Residents of block 104 in the Jeju City () Yeondong Daelim Apartments were evacuated after a fire was reported on the third floor of the building around 10:20 Friday morning.
Firefighters extinguished the blaze within 30 minutes of their arrival on the scene.
Two residents were taken to the hospital to be treated for smoke inhalation.
Police and fire authorities say smoke was noticed coming from an oven in a third-floor apartment. They have launched an investigation into the exact cause of the fire and are questioning the owner of the apartment and witnesses.

NEWS.TITLE: Arirang [Employment Roadmap ]
NEWS.TEXT:
[Ŀ] Turning to Arirang now, and the government's push to spur job creation in the country. Several measures have been proposed by the Park Geun-hye administration to achieve its goal of 70 percent employment. And As Arirang's (ѿ) Kim Han-ul now reports, the efforts may change the job paradigm itself in Korea.
[Ʈ] Currently, around 64 percent of Koreans who are able to work, have jobs. But President Park Geun-hye has been pledging to raise the employment rate to 70 percent since before coming to office earlier this year.
Seoul announces roadmap to 70% employment rate
On Tuesday, the finance and related government ministries announced a plan for achieving that goal, with Prime Minister Chung Hong-won calling for a radical change in the way the nation gets to work.
Interview / Chung Hong-won, Prime minister
"We need to shift away from male-centric jobs with long hours, and move towards flexible work hours that can be applied to everyone. We need to spread the culture of balancing work and family throughout our society."
The government plans to create around 2-point-4 million jobs by 2017, or roughly 480-thousand jobs per year.
The government says this goal cannot be achieved using the old methods, and is proposing four objectives:creating new jobs by fostering the so-called creative economy; implementing flexible work hours and reforming the work culture; bringing marginalized members of the workforce -- women, the elderly and young people -- back into the labor market; and lastly, boosting corporate accountability to ensure greater transparency and fair business practices.
Arirang reporter / Kim Han-ul
"Starting next year, it will be mandatory for regional governments to publicize their job creation goals, and the government plans to create financial incentives for companies that are actively involved in job creation efforts.
Kim Han-ul, Arirang News."
